Headline.Para: Public transport fares should not be pegged directly to cost

LeadPara.Para: Transport hogged the spotlight in this year's Budget, if nothing else, for the record expenditure of $13.7 billion slated for financial year 2018.

The amount is clearly no small change. It represents a 50 per cent jump from the previous year's expenditure, and puts transport just a mite below the $14.8 billion earmarked for defence - traditionally the cost leader in any Budget.

TailParas.Para: In the same breath, the Government hinted strongly that public transport fares would have to go up - not just because of the huge increase in expenditure, but also because service standards had risen.

It was Tampines GRC MP Cheng Li Hui who asserted that fare adjustments had lagged behind the rise in operating costs. She observed that there was a disconnect between how operating cost had soared, and how fares had in fact fallen in recent years.
Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan cued in quickly, saying: "I agree with Ms Cheng Li Hui that the current formula is inadequate. It can be improved to better track total costs."
The minister said the Public Transport Council was reviewing the fare formula. Clearly, the underlying objective would be to better align fares with operating cost.

This may sound logical, and even reasonable. But in fact, it flies in the face of a longstanding philosophy of pegging our bus and train fares to macroeconomic determinants rather than operating cost.

This philosophy has served Singapore well, instilling a discipline among operators, which cannot - unlike in other jurisdictions - simply pass cost on to consumers.

Essentially, the fare adjustment formula is based on three components: change in inflation rate over the preceding year; change in average wage over the preceding year; and a productivity extraction that allows any productivity gain to be shared between operators and commuters.

About five years ago, there was a call to review the formula, so that operating cost could be better reflected in fares. During the last review in 2013, the Public Transport Council recommended excluding rises in property and car prices in the inflation rate. Crucially, it proposed an energy component to reflect changes in fuel and electricity costs.
The recommendations were accepted, and the revised formula took effect from 2013 to last year.
But because oil prices spiralled downwards from 2014, bottoming out in 2016, the new energy component helped push fares lower all round for a sustained period.

Operators have had to incur higher costs, but these were not recurring costs. In the case of SMRT, the dominant rail player here, it had to ramp up on resources and expenses to deal with repairs and maintenance, which arguably should have been staged more progressively over the years. Over at SBS Transit, cost surged because it had to ramp up manpower for the opening of new phases of the Downtown Line.

If the rise in operating expenses is on the back of such cost spurts, would it be wise to overhaul the entire fare formula? This is especially when higher expenses will pay off for public transport operators in the years ahead, as ridership continues to grow.
Also, oil prices will eventually revert to pre-2014 levels, simply because of rising demand. When that happens, the formula will result in higher fares.
The practice of basing public transport fares on macro components is not unique to Singapore. Hong Kong uses a similar formula, with varying weightages for the various components.
The difference is that Singapore uses core inflation, applies an energy component, and institutes a reality check that can cap fares to ensure they remain affordable to the masses.
Singapore also has a targeted approach to helping the needy pay for public transport.
This method has maintained a fine balance between the interests of operators and commuters.

Now that the Government has taken a more active role in subsidising public transport - even assuming revenue risk, in the case of buses - the motivation for changing the fare formula is understandable.
But lest we tread carefully, we will end up like London, where fares and government subsidies keep rising - an unsustainable situation.

Yes, the "user pays" principle is sound, and if service standards rise meaningfully, consumers should pay more. But this principle must not be overemphasised in the area of public transport, whose value proposition extends beyond the end user.
The country on the whole benefits from a superior public transport network, and the Government itself benefits from enhanced land value along rail lines.
So, while it is tempting to pass more cost to commuters, we should not lose sight of the big picture.
